p:
Lab capacities are then defined as a fraction of the ideal number of tests assigned to each lab:
Q l
=
m ¯
λ LC
,
where λ LC is a parameter. Values of the parameter larger than 1 correspond to a situation in which reagent availability is the main bottleneck for testing, while smaller values indicate that laboratories have structural deficiencies which limit the number of swabs they can test, even when reagent is abundant. Each lab can procure reagent from its λ LF closest factories, and can send swabs to other laboratories in the same region. A parameter λ LL gives the maximum distance at which two labs in different regions can exchange swabs. In particular, when
λ LL
= 0
we forbid cross-regional collaboration and sharing of testing capacity.
